Package jrapl

Class AsyncEnergyMonitorJavaSide

  • java.lang.Object
    • jrapl.JRAPL
      • jrapl.AsyncEnergyMonitorJavaSide
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable
    public class AsyncEnergyMonitorJavaSide
extends JRAPL
implements java.lang.Runnable
    Reads and stores sytem energy consumption in a background thread.
    Meant to record the progression of energy consumption of a program run in the main thread.
    Spawns a therad between this.start() and this.stop().
    Every individual energy sample is the energy consumed (joules) over the course of a set millisecond sampling rate
    Energy read from three power domains: DRAM or GPU (depending on CPU model), CPU core, CPU package

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      AsyncEnergyMonitorJavaSide()
      Initializes sample collector with a default sampling rate setting of 10 milliseconds

      Initializes sample collector with the sampling rate passed as paramter

      • AsyncEnergyMonitorJavaSide

        public AsyncEnergyMonitorJavaSide​(int s)

    • Method Detail

      • run

        public void run()
        Do not call this directly from the main thread. It is called and run internally by the Thread class via this.start(). Runs a loop, continually reading energy consumption over the samplingRate and stores the sample. Loop is controlled by an internal boolean, which is set to stop once the main thread calls this.stop()
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable

      • start

        public void start()
        Starts collecting and storing energy samples in a separate thread. Continually takes and stores energy samples in the background while main thread runs. Will run until main thread calls this.stop().

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Stops collecting and storing energy samples.

      • reInit

        public void reInit()
        Resets the object for reuse.
        Call this if you intend to reuse the same object for energy collection after already using it.
        Clears out the current list of samples stored in the object.

      • getLastKSamples

        public double[][] getLastKSamples​(int k)
        Returns K most recent stored samples. Each samples is a double[] of the form
        [dram/gpu energy, core energy, package energy].
        If K is greater than the amount of samples, returns all samples
        Parameters:
        k - Number of most recent samples
        Returns:
        An array of the K most recent samples.

      • getSamplingRate

        public int getSamplingRate()
        Gets the sampling rate for the thread to collect samples.
        Returns:
        The sampling rate (in milliseconds)

      • setSamplingRate

        public void setSamplingRate​(int s)
        Sets the sampling rate over which to take samples
        Parameters:
        s - sampling rate (in milliseconds)

      • getNumReadings

        public int getNumReadings()
        Gets the number of samples the object has currently collected
        Returns:
        number of samples collected so far

      • writeToFile

        public void writeToFile​(java.lang.String fileName)
        Dumps all samples to file, along with the sampling rate. Same format as this.toString()
        Parameters:
        fileName - name of file to write to

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        CSV format of all data collected. First two lines are the sampling rate and a header describing which power domain each column's energy samples represent
        Format:
        Sampling Rate: xxx (ms)
        dram/gpu,core,pkg
        xxx,xxx,xxx
        xxx,xxx,xxx
        xxx,xxx,xxx
        xxx,xxx,xxx
        ... et cetera ...
        note that only one of "dram" and "gpu" will be listed for the first column, depending on your CPU model
        each entry per line is tab delimited
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        Human readable interpretation of the data stored in the object
